description: Probably from Middle Low German pūs, pūskatte or Dutch poes (“puss, cat”, slang for “vulva”), ultimately from a common Germanic word for cat, perhaps ultimately imitative of a sound made to get its attention (compare Arabic بسة (bissa)).
Akin to West Frisian poes, Low German Puus, Puuskatte, Danish pus, dialectal Swedish kattepus, Norwegian pus.

Found also in several other European, North African and West Asian languages; compare Romanian pisică, Persian پیشی‎ (piši)
and Sardinian pisittu.

entries.meaning: (informal, often as a term of address) A cat.
examples: Our local theatre is showing Puss in Boots.
Come here, puss! I've got some milk for you.

entries.meaning: (dated, endearing) A girl or young woman, or any child.

examples: He then began to beat about, in the same language and in the same manner as if he had been beating for a hare; and at last cried out, "Soho! Puss is not far off. Here's her form, upon my soul; I believe I may cry stole away."

entries.meaning: (uncountable, vulgar, slang, metonymically) Sex with a woman.
(vulgar, slang, chiefly Canada, US) A coward; a wuss; someone who is unable to stand up for themself.

description: Of Celtic origin, from or akin to Irish pus (“mouth, lip”), from Middle Irish bus.

examples: Shut your puss before I shut it for you.
She gave him a slap in the puss.
It didn't move as much, and the same teary puss leaked from its eyes.
